1. The Song dynasty in China started in the year 960 AD and lasted until 1279 AD. However, a significant precursor to the Song dynasty was the Later Zhou Dynasty. In 960, Zhao Kuangyin, a former military general and a Song imperial relative, declared himself the emperor and took the name Zhao Kuangyin (also known as Emperor Taizu of Song) after the capital at Hangzhou. His reign laid the foundation for the new imperial regime that would establish its own capital in Hangzhou and shift from the regional control of several warlords who came to power after the fall of the Tang Dynasty. 

The historical characteristics of the Song Dynasty include its marked improvements in technology (like the adoption of gunpowder), innovations in agriculture leading to an increase in food output and availability, advances in transportation technology, military reforms, and an extensive system of writing laws, as well as further development in both Confucian education and the arts. The establishment and enforcement of a well-organized examination system that determined access to government positions also occurred. China experienced relative prosperity and stability under the Song Dynasty, with growth in commercial activities like the silk road, and extensive relations with Korea and Mongolia.
